keyTakeAways: Sean Grayson, a 31-year-old Illinois sheriff’s deputy, is charged with first-degree murder, aggravated battery with a firearm, and official misconduct for shooting Sonya Massey in her home on July 6, 2024.

Massey, a Black woman and single mother, was responding to a call about a suspected prowler, and Grayson reportedly interpreted her comment ‘I rebuke you in the name of Jesus’ as a threat, leading to a fatal shooting.
Body camera footage shows Grayson entering the home, removing a hot pan, and reacting defensively when Massey picks it up again, before firing three shots.
Massey had a history of mental health struggles, including prior admission to a mental health facility, and had made multiple 911 calls in the days before the shooting.
Grayson was unaware of Massey’s mental health history or prior 911 calls, and had a prior record including a DUI conviction and army ejection for drunken driving with a weapon.
Grayson had multiple short-term policing jobs, with documented performance concerns including poor report writing and lack of evidence management.

The shooting prompted public scrutiny and led to the resignation of Sangamon County Sheriff Jack Campbell and a state-level law change under Governor JB Pritzker requiring full disclosure of police candidates’ personal and employment background records.
The trial was relocated from Springfield to Peoria due to national attention and public concern over transparency in law enforcement practices.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The murder trial of Illinois sheriff’s deputy Sean Grayson, accused of fatally shooting Black woman Sonya Massey in her Springfield home on July 6, 2024, is set to begin on October 20, 2025. The incident occurred after Grayson, responding to a call about a suspected prowler, confronted Massey over a pan of hot water, misinterpreted her religious comment as a threat, and fired three times. Massey, a single mother with a history of mental health issues, had made multiple 911 calls prior to the shooting, which Grayson was unaware of. Grayson has a troubled past, including DUIs and being ejected from the Army, and had poor performance evaluations in previous policing jobs. The shooting prompted the resignation of Sheriff Jack Campbell and led to a new Illinois law requiring full disclosure of police candidates’ personal and employment backgrounds. The trial was relocated from Springfield to Peoria to accommodate national attention and ensure impartiality.
